title: Orientales Express: Pyrenees Big Ride

Orientales Express: Pyrenees Big Ride

The modern Tour de France, indeed modern cycling, has a keen sense of the aesthetic. The Champs-Élysées at dusk, Les Lacets de Montvernier, Mont-St-Michel, even a slightly half-hearted stage départ under the Millau Viaduct, all create the sort of visual feast for which the Tour has an insatiable appetite.

Even if their sporting value is limited, such shareable, likeable moments are the driving force behind the massive media coverage that makes Le Tour the behemoth it is.

In that sense it’s obvious why the 2021 race used a particular 23km of the route that Cyclist is about to ride at the Mediterranean end of the French Pyrenees.

On Stage 14, after 166 of the day’s 184 kilometres, the pros ascended the Col de Saint-Louis by way of a spiralling road that is known locally as ‘l’Escargot’. Trek-Segafredo’s Bauke Mollema would win the stage from a solo break, cresting the climb more than a minute clear of his nearest rivals and easily holding his lead all the way to the line.

You may have ridden the 270˚ Nus de Sa Corbata on the eternally popular Sa Calobra climb in Mallorca; The Snail is similar in that it loops around and under itself, but with an extra 180˚ of twist.

You can imagine the giddy excitement in the offices of ASO – and Cyclist for that matter – when this wondrous piece of road was discovered.

Spanish influences

Despite the long shadows cast by the Col du Tourmalet and friends in neighbouring French departments and adjacent Andorra, there’s a lot more to the cycling appeal of this eastern region of the Pyrenees than an asphalt helter-skelter, and much of it is actually thanks to the milder amplitude of the topography, not in spite of it.

Free from the defining parameters of the densely packed soaring peaks in the heart of the range, here in the Pyrenees-Orientales there are simply more roads. They disperse what little traffic there is into practically nothing and follow the landscape with a rare empathy, appearing to always go around rather than through the terrain.

I have never come across more corners, which can be sickening when you’re a passenger in a car, but it’s pure joy as a cyclist. Most of all, though, the area is known for its spectacular gorges, and our route for today includes two of the best.

I’m joined by two fellow ex-patriots, friends Adrian Howell and Mike Cotty (of Col Collective fame), both super-strong cyclists who jumped at the chance to take on a Big Ride.

We’ve driven over from the Hautes-Pyrenees, where Mike and I both run cycling holiday businesses (mine’s called Escape To The Pyrenees, seeing as you ask) and as we roll out of the small town of Prades at 9am we’re immediately struck by how sharply this end of the mountain range contrasts.

As the Golden Eagle flies (no crows here, the eagles ate them all), I’m 200km from home but it feels like a thousand.

The flora is distinctly Spanish-looking and so are many of the town names; the village of Catllar is the gateway to the mountains, just outside Prades. The road signs are even bilingual – French and Catalan – and carry the red and yellow colours of the latter, not the blue, white and red of France.

We’ve already been climbing gently for a while when we swing right onto the 10.7km Col de Roque-Jalere. With fresh legs we tap up the moderate gradient briskly, excitement battling discipline. It may only average 5.7% but there are some grippy ramps along the way and it’s steeper near the 991m peak.

We’re at the top in 45 minutes and it feels like a good downpayment on the day. A glance at my bike computer shows 650m gained, a firm reminder that, despite the two prominent peaks on the route profile, we’re far from halfway done with climbing.

As we eat some food and don gilets for the descent, we look out into the haze across the broad valley.

On a clear day the 2,784m Pic du Canigou would dominate the skyline. So prominent is the Canigou, only 50km from the sea and sat on the end of the Pyrenees like a bookstop, that it was once thought to be the highest mountain in the range (when in fact it’s over 600m short and not even in the top 100). It retains a near-talismanic significance to the area as a Catalan symbol and, more practically, the region’s main tourist draw.

By gorge!

It’s a shame to miss an iconic view but swift recompense arrives 4km into the writhing and surprisingly well-surfaced descent when the next valley suddenly reveals itself.

Our progress remains rapid as the descent hands off to 20km of false flat and then to a strong tailwind. The road rises and pierces the looming ridgeline, spitting us out into the town of Saint-Paul-de-Fenouillet and towards the next wall of rock.

A small climb takes us to the head of Gorges de Galamus. With 60km covered it’s a bit early for a cafe stop, but you stop where the cafes are and this one comes with an incredible view into the gorge for good measure.

While the gorge itself was carved patiently over millennia by the River Agly, the road was built in the 1890s by men hanging from ropes using crude tools such as crowbars to create a channel in the rock. It’s only one car wide with just a smattering of passing places, and so low is the overhanging rock that we sometimes feel compelled to duck.

The gorge road is downhill and the southerly wind is boosted by the Venturi effect of the funnel-like walls, so speed comes easily and feels magnified by the constant tight corners, very close rock face and big drop.

If I let go of the brakes it’s about as close as road cycling gets to the intensity of downhill mountain biking and seems ripe for a Red Bull event. The Tour misses out, though. You couldn’t even fit a team car with bikes on the roof down here, let alone the various rolling novelties of La Caravane.

At Cubières-sur-Cinoble we turn west across the top of our route and collect a couple more cols – Mike’s influence rubbing off.

The Cols de Bancarel (0.8km, 5%) and Linas (4km, 4%) barely seem worthy of naming though, especially with the monolithic Pech de Bugarach towering above us. We swing around it and zigzag south on rolling roads, unable to recall when we last saw a car.

The second ‘zig’ takes us towards The Snail. If you were concentrating too hard on the downhill approach you might not notice it through the trees, in which case it will stop you in your tracks as it bursts into view.

Framed by the steep cliffs that make it necessary and with a view into the next valley as a backdrop, it’s quite something.

Much as we’re tempted to linger and marvel at the looping l’Escargot, we have to push on. We have 63km and a huge climb still to go, and the weather that’s blowing in doesn’t look so kind.

Any notions we may have held of bobsleigh-like descending are immediately dismissed, however. There’s just so much loose gravel on the recently dressed surface. Our guess is that ASO chose to send the Tour up The Snail rather than down it as much to save having to sweep away all the gravel as for the prolonged helicopter beauty shot.

Col of the wild

Having negotiated the tricky descent, the D117 from Caudiès-de-Fenouillèdes to the Pont d’Alies is the right road at the right time – wider, faster, beautifully surfaced, with a tailwind and still quiet. It’s ideal for ticking off some kilometres so we fall into line and swap punchy turns.

The 2.5km Col du Campérié is more false flat than climb and is dismissed in the big ring. Its descent is equally easy and turns into a supertucking slipstream battle, a nose thumbed to the UCI’s new regulations banning the position.

The turn south after 94km is significant for several reasons: it takes us towards the Gorge de Saint-Georges, another scenic high point of the route, plus it sets us on a heading back towards the incoming weather. Most of all, it kicks off 23km of climbing, with 5km of grinding amuse-bouche before the Col de Jau begins in earnest.

Rising 1,034m in 18km, the Jau blows apart any ideas that the Pyrenees-Orientales can’t be every bit as challenging as the rest of the range. And if its 5.8% average sounds tame, we haven’t accounted for the two stretches of 3km that average 8% and peak at 10%, by which time we have over 100km and 2,000m in the legs.

It’s suddenly a lot warmer too, and the sweat is pouring off us as we climb, an inevitable flicker of competitiveness descending over our mini peloton as the increasing gradient lights a fire under our toes.

The Col de Jau has only made three appearances in the Tour (1976, 1993 and 2001) and always in the middle of the stage as the peloton heads west towards the more famous Pyrenean cols.

It’s not a climb that would ever be a highlight of the Tour – it’s not hard enough to split the bunch, and there is too much overhanging rock and tree cover for the TV pictures – but it is a fantastic climb for the rest of us.

The Jau is pretty, varied, traffic-free and just about challenging enough to feel rewarding once you reach the top. We climb between rock walls, through a short tunnel and under a canopy of trees barely divided by this slender strip of tarmac. Such is the escapism it feels close to a gravel riding experience but without going off-road, which sounds like the best of both worlds.

The climb forks after 6km. Right would take us over the Col de Garabeil (1,262m) and towards the ski stations of Les Angles, Pyrénées 2000 and Font-Romeu. Instead we turn left for the final 12km to the summit and notice the temperature fall several degrees in as many minutes.

The first raindrops arrive 5km from the summit, but they’re sporadic enough to suggest they might amount to nothing more. A kilometre later we’re sheltering under trees from persistent drizzle as we shove some more fuel in.

Adrian feels on the edge of a bonk and rapid-fires a few gels to catch it just in time. We know we can’t afford to hit empty yet: the Jau isn’t done with us and the long descent will require alertness. We’re just hoping the rain doesn’t get worse.

Down the water slide

The first clap of thunder comes within seconds of clipping back in and the final 3km are climbed in the heaviest rain I think I’ve ever ridden in. It’s falling in drops so big that each is like a water bomb exploding on the rapidly flooding road.

The temperature has halved to 13˚C but thankfully the rain itself feels warm. This storm had been forecast for tomorrow, part of a system that has put a third of France on ‘orange alert’.

At the summit the trees give way to dense cloud, though I only realise we’re at the top because the car carrying photographer Sami has stopped, which at least gives us the chance to don rain jackets as lightning flashes directly overhead.

We really need to get off this exposed summit fast but, frankly, I’m on the wrong bike. As much as I love my Swift, this debris-strewn road is shining an unforgiving light on its 25mm tyre clearance, and the limits of its rim brakes are being cruelly exposed by descending in torrential rain.

Mike and Adrian both have disc brakes and 28mm and 30mm tyres respectively. I’m usually an advocate of #SaveTheRimBrake, but today it’s more a case of #SaveTheRimBrakeForSunnyDays. I don’t get dropped but my stress levels rise in inverse proportion to my stopping power.

Bleary eyed from descending without glasses, we roll into Prades and congratulate each other on a ride that has left us buzzing. The Pyrenees-Orientales may lack the spectacle of the high mountains further west, but they have a substance that has left me profoundly satisfied.

The Catalonia complexity

The region that is a bit France, a bit Catalonia

It might look like the Pyrenees-Orientales has an identity crisis, torn between being French and Catalan, but in reality it’s more a crisis of understanding for visitors, albeit one made more complicated by recent events.

The department broadly corresponds to the old territory of Northern or French Catalonia, which was once part of Spain but was handed over to France in 1659 at the end of the Franco-Spanish war.

The Spanish political crisis of Catalan separatism, which peaked in 2017 with an attempted referendum declared illegal by the government, has echoed across the border and there is a small but highly vocal minority campaigning for Northern and Southern Catalonia to be united and independent. The prevalence of Catalonian iconography and language easily gives visitors the impression that this opinion is far more commonly held than is the case.

Whether or not wealthy Spanish Catalunya would want the considerably less affluent French Catalonia to join it is a question that never quite gets answered. What’s clear is that this part of France strongly identifies as Catalonian and French, and that the regional and national identities can co-exist.

How we did it

Travel

From the UK it’s a lengthy ten-hour drive from St Malo if you take the excellent overnight ferry, or 12 hours from Calais. The best-connected airports are Toulouse and Barcelona, equidistant at 2.5 hours of driving away. The small airports at Carcassonne and Perpignan are closer and between them offer flights to London, Birmingham, Dublin and Manchester.

Accommodation

We rented an Airbnb house 7km south of Prades in the hammeau (hamlet) of Clara, but Prades does offer a few hotels and plenty of attractive chambres d’hôtes (B&Bs).

Thanks

Many thanks to JB for assisting and driving photographer Sami all day; Adrian and Mike for joining Cyclist on what was a very long day after the five-hour drive home; Sami for shooting tirelessly and smiling constantly, even in the rain; and Adrian again for cooking a stonking curry.
